title: Painful Knee
description: A painful knee means your knee hurts or feels uncomfortable. It can happen due to injuries, overuse, or other health problems. It might feel sharp, dull, or achy, and may cause swelling or difficulty moving the knee.

sections.heading: Symptoms
sections.content:
Pain in the front, back, or side of the knee

Swelling around the knee

Stiffness or difficulty moving the knee

Weakness or the knee feeling unstable

Popping or clicking sounds

Bruising or redness (if injured)

Warmth or tenderness around the knee

sections.heading: Common Causes
sections.content:
**Injury:**

Sprains/Strains: Stretching or tearing of ligaments or muscles

Ligament injuries: Damage to knee ligaments (eg, ACL, MCL)

Meniscus tear: Damage to cartilage in the knee

Fractures: Broken bones in or around the knee

Dislocation: When the kneecap moves out of place


**Overuse or Age-Related:**

Osteoarthritis: Wear and tear of the knee’s cartilage

Tendinitis: Inflammation in the tendon below the kneecap

Bursitis: Inflammation of fluid-filled sacs near the knee

IT band syndrome: Tightness in the leg's side band causing knee pain


**Other Health Problems:**

Gout: A type of arthritis causing knee pain and swelling

Rheumatoid arthritis: A disease that affects the joints

Baker’s cyst: A fluid-filled lump behind the knee that causes pain and swelling

sections.heading: Home Care Tips
sections.content:
Rest: Avoid putting weight on the painful knee

Ice: Put an ice pack on the knee for 15-20 minutes to reduce swelling

Compression: Wrap the knee with an elastic bandage for support

Elevation: Raise the knee to reduce swelling

Pain relievers: Take ibuprofen or paracetamol for pain

Knee brace or sleeve: For extra support

Stretch and strengthen the knee with exercises (if your doctor suggests it)

sections.heading: When to See a Doctor
sections.content:
If pain lasts more than a few days or gets worse

If your knee is very swollen, bruised, or hard to move

If you feel sharp pain after falling or injuring the knee

If the knee feels weak or like it might give out

If there’s a popping sound followed by pain or swelling

If you can’t stand or walk on the knee

If you have a fever or redness around the knee

sections.heading: When to Go to the ER
sections.content:
If the knee pain is severe after an injury

If the knee looks deformed (out of place)

If you can’t move or straighten the knee

If there’s fluid or blood coming from the knee

If you have signs of infection: redness, warmth, fever

If there’s severe swelling that doesn’t get better with rest and ice

sections.heading: Treatment from a Doctor
sections.content:
X-rays or MRI to check for fractures or tears

Physical therapy to help strengthen the knee

Medications (for pain and inflammation)

Injections (for pain or swelling)

In some cases, surgery to repair or replace parts of the knee

sections.heading: What Not to Do
sections.content:
Don’t ignore pain that lasts for a long time

Don’t force your knee to move if it hurts

Don’t try to diagnose yourself—always ask a doctor for help

Avoid sitting or standing still for long periods—move around to keep your knee from getting stiff
